column2: accept that you are feeling very blah and negative.   3. Donâ€™t think about results and how well you think youâ€™ll do
column3: as this could raise your feelings of anxiety and fear
column4: just think about â€œright nowâ€ and the first thing you can do.   4. Accept that life is tough
column5: and is full of things that suck â€“ but recognise that doing hard stuff is better in the end. Youâ€™ll likely have more choices and freedom
column6: if you do.   5. Just do a little bit for now â€“ then give yourself a proper break â€“ then go back and do some more â€“ and soon youâ€™ll find youâ€™re in the flow.   6. Donâ€™t allow your mind to wander and think of other things. Stay focused for that short time â€“ and then stop

jocundasykes 160991207169 "2017-05-23 18:05:12 GMT" https://jocundasykes.tumblr.com/post/160991207169/ron-is-awesome-sauce-rosalui-lupinatic "ron-is-awesome-sauce:  rosalui:  lupinatic:  fleamontpotter:  Something that really bothers me about peopleâ€™s hatred towards Ron is that unless you grew up really poor you have no idea what itâ€™s like and how much it affects you. Especially if you grow up poor surrounded by rich friends. The jealousy seriously eats you alive and the way Ron acted was perfectly understandable.Â   Over twenty years later
column2: Iâ€™ll still never forget the day one of my classmates told me to just ask my parents for more money
column3: as though I was literally too thick to work out the obvious solution. Because in her world
column4: it was that simple. Or the day my teacher gave me anÂ â€˜are you even trying for a believable lieâ€™? look when I had to tell him my parents couldnâ€™t afford to send me on a low-cost excursion. Or how for an entire school year
column5: I had to wear a school uniform skirt so small it left angry marks on my waist every day
column6: because my mother begged me to make it last just one more year. The day everyone thought it was hilarious to ruin my pencil case
column7: and even more hilarious that I was so upset and claimed that my parents would be furious with me - LOL
column8: that silly girl! Theyâ€™ll just buy her a new one
column10: they couldnâ€™t and it was). And yeah
column11: I had my fair share of second-hand underwear too
column12: like another character who grew up in poverty. The utter shock I felt when I realized other families not only had air conditioning
column13: but also used it regularlyâ€¦ the jealousy I felt when everyone else had nice formal wear and I had whatever my parents could manage to getâ€¦ the list goes on and on. And thatâ€™s on top of a bunch of other struggles and disadvantages I had.  But to hear Ron critics talk
column14: he was the worst person alive if he ever even dared to want nice things for himself instead of just nobly being happy other people had them. â€˜Why is everything I own rubbish?â€™ is not a permissible attitude
column15: not even for a moment.  I see a lot of people making fun/disapproving of how Ron is always stuffing his face with food and it INFURIATES ME.When you grow up fucking poor you learn to take advantage of free food when you have it.Asshats.  Also does anyone realize the sheer fortitude Ron had to have to invite Harry over to his house!? I could not invite my better off friends over to my house because things were literally falling apart inside of it and my family didnâ€™t have the means to fix it and it ate me up inside to not be able to have my best friend over to my house when I spent the better half of my teenage life sleeping over at her house because my parents and I didnâ€™t want her to see how rundown the inside of our home was. Ron was so nervous about what Harry would say about his house and was embrassed by the state of it but he saw  Harry needed somewhere to stay and he opened up his home to him. People who have always been well off wouldnâ€™t understand the magnitude of that action. Ron is a damn treasure and anyone who hates him because of his jealousy canâ€™t understand the deeper meaning behind it. " False text

jocundasykes 160881786179 "2017-05-20 19:16:37 GMT" https://jocundasykes.tumblr.com/post/160881786179/when-doctors-discriminate "andreashettle:  avioletmind:   Are medical professionals biased against the mentally ill?    THE first time it was an ear
column2: nose and throat doctor. I had an emergency visit for an ear infection
column3: which was causing a level of pain I hadnâ€™t experienced since giving birth. He looked at the list of drugs I was taking for my bipolar disorder and closed my chart.   â€œI donâ€™t feel comfortable prescribing anything
column4: â€ he said. â€œNot with everything else youâ€™re on.â€ He said it was probably safe to take Tylenol and politely but firmly indicated it was time for me to go. The next day my eardrum ruptured and I was left with minor but permanent hearing loss.  Another time I was lying on the examining table when a gastroenterologist I was seeing for the first time looked at my list of drugs and shook her finger in my face. â€œYou better get yourself together psychologically
column6: â€œor your stomach is never going to get any better.â€ If you met me
column7: youâ€™d never know I was mentally ill. In fact
column8: Iâ€™ve gone through most of my adult life without anyone ever knowing â€” except when Iâ€™ve had to reveal it to a doctor. And that revelation changes everything. It wipes clean the rest of my rÃ©sumÃ©
column11: reduces me to a diagnosis. I was surprised when
column13: my psychopharmacologist said this sort of behavior was all too common. At least 14 studies have shown that patients with a serious mental illness receive worse medical care than â€œnormalâ€ people. Last year the World Health Organization called the stigma and discrimination endured by people with mental health conditions â€œa hidden human rights emergency.â€   I never knew it until I started poking around
column14: but this particular kind of discriminatory doctoring has a name. Itâ€™s called â€œdiagnostic overshadowing.â€  According to a review of studies done by the Institute of Psychiatry at Kingâ€™s College
column16: it happens a lot. As a result
column17: people with a serious mental illness â€” including bipolar disorder
column19: schizophrenia and schizoaffective disorder â€” end up with wrong diagnoses and are under-treated. That is a problem
column20: because if you are given one of these diagnoses you probably also suffer from one or more chronic physical conditions: though no one quite knows why
column22: irritable bowel syndrome and mitral valve prolapse often go hand in hand with bipolar disorder. Less mysterious is the weight gain associated with most of the drugs used to treat bipolar disorder and schizophrenia
column23: which can easily snowball into diabetes
column25: high cholesterol and cardiovascular disease. The drugs can also sedate you into a state of zombiedom
column26: which can make going to the gym â€” or even getting off your couch â€” virtually impossible. Itâ€™s little wonder that many people with a serious mental illness donâ€™t seek medical attention when they need it. As a result
column27: many of us end up in emergency rooms â€” where doctors
column28: confronted with an endless stream of drug addicts who come to their door looking for an easy fix â€” are often all too willing to equate mental illness with drug-seeking behavior and refuse to prescribe pain medication. I should know: a few years ago I had a persistent migraine
column29: and after weeks trying to get an appointment with any of the handful of headache specialists in New York City
column30: I broke down and went to the E.R. My husband filled out paperwork and gave the nurse my list of drugs. The doctors finally agreed to give me something stronger than what my psychopharmacologist could prescribe for the pain and hooked me up to an IV.  I lay there for hours wearing sunglasses to block out the fluorescent light
column31: waiting for the pain relievers to kick in. But the headache continued. â€œThey gave you saline and electrolytes
column32: â€ my psychopharmacologist said later. â€œWelcome to being bipolar.â€   When I finally saw the specialist two weeks later (during which time my symptoms included numbness and muscle weakness)
column33: she accused me of being â€œa serious cocaine userâ€ (I donâ€™t touch the stuff) and of displaying symptoms of â€œla belle indifference
column34: â€ a 19th-century term for a kind of hysteria in which the patient converts emotional symptoms into physical ones â€” i.e.
column35: it was all in my head.  Indeed
column36: given my experience over the last two decades
column37: I shouldnâ€™t have been surprised by the statistics I found in the exhaustive report â€œMorbidity and Mortality in People with Serious Mental Illness
column38: â€ a review of studies published in 2006 that provides an overview of recommendations and general call to arms by the National Association of State Mental Health Program Directors. The take-away: people who suffer from a serious mental illness and use the public health care system die 25 years earlier than those without one.   True
column40: accounting for 30 to 40 percent of early deaths. But 60 percent die of preventable or treatable conditions. First on the list is
column42: cardiovascular disease. Two studies showed that patients with both a mental illness and a cardiovascular condition received about half the number of follow-up interventions
column43: like bypass surgery or cardiac catheterization
column44: after having a heart attack than did the â€œnormalâ€ cardiac patients. The report also contains a list of policy recommendations
column45: including designating patients with serious mental illnesses as a high-priority population; coordinating and integrating mental and physical health care for such people; education for health care workers and patients; and a quality-improvement process that supports increased access to physical health care and ensures appropriate prevention
column46: screening and treatment services. Such changes
column48: might make a real difference. And after seven years of no change
column49: signs of movement are popping up
column50: particularly among academic programs aimed at increasing awareness of mental health issues. Several major medical schools now have programs in the medical humanities
column51: an emerging field that draws on diverse disciplines including the visual arts
column53: music and science to make medical students think differently about their patients. And Johns Hopkins offers a doctor of public health with a specialization in mental health. Perhaps the most notable of these efforts â€” and so far the only one of its kind â€” is the narrative medicine program at Columbia University Medical Center
column54: which starts with the premise that there is a disconnect between health care and patients and that health care workers need to start listening to what their patients are telling them
column55: and not just looking at whatâ€™s written on their charts. According to the programâ€™s mission statement
column56: â€œThe effective practice of health care requires the ability to recognize
column59: and act on the stories and plights of others. Medicine practiced with narrative competence is a model for humane and effective medical practice.â€ We can only hope that humanizing programs like this one become a requirement for all health care workers. Maybe then â€œfirst
column60: do no harmâ€ will apply to everyone
column61: even the mentally ill.  By JULIANN GAREY Published: August 10
column62: 2013 The author of the novel â€œToo Bright to Hear Too Loud to Seeâ€ and a co-editor of â€œVoices of Bipolar Disorder: The Healing Companion.â€    Reblogging because this is the sort of thing that needs signal boosting the heck out of it. Probably many of the people who see this in my Tumblr are people who already know from first-hand experience as a patient. Probably most of the people who even know my Tumblr exists are not in a position to perpetuate this problem (because they arenâ€™t doctors). Â But I figure if more people get info like this circulating
column63: maybe eventually someone in a better position to reach more doctors with this kind of information and open serious dialogue about how to address the problem will come across this. Until then
column64: at least a better informed patient population can
column66: be in a better position to advocate for themselvesâ€”if not always as individuals then perhaps as groups. " False link
